subject: Re: assertEquals IT IS SORTED
msgSnippet: Thank you all for you fast responses and you answers. After digging a bit more I found the problem: when comparing entity beans you actually compare their
messageBody:
Thank you all for you fast responses and you answers.
After digging a bit more I found the problem: when comparing entity
beans you actually compare their primary keys.In the primary key
class the developper must write the hashCode method and the equals
method. Now, I use to use primitve types (int, long) for holding the
value of the primary key. But I had to change to wrapper class
(Integer, Long) and for those == does not work, I should have use
equals to compare the pk.
Stupid me.... :-)

Thank you all,
Benjamin

--- In junit@y..., Robert Sartin <sartin@a...> wrote:
>
> --- Jason Rogers <jacaetev@y...> wrote:
> > This seems highly unlikely. Two objects pointing to the same
> > reference are
> > absolutely equal. Are you sure you copied the message properly?
>
> The output looks like it is from a toString() method that calls
> toString() on a contained object that does not override toString().
The
> contained objects appear to be the same references, but the
containing
> objects might not be, and might not implement equals correctly.
>
> Regards,
>
> Rob
